dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so, I was reading this article, um, the other day, about immunotherapy and the immune system, and it had, like, a really, really wild take on things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so, I was reading this article, um, the other day, about immunotherapy and the immune system, and it had, like, a really, really wild take on things.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? What was so wild about it? Like, usually, we're talking about breakthroughs, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? What was so wild about it? Like, usually, we're talking about breakthroughs, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, exactly! But this article, uh, it actually started by saying how, like, a lot of the foundational work by people like Allison and Honjo, those Nobel winners? It failed to lead to *effective* immunotherapies for most patients.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, exactly! But this article, uh, it actually started by saying how, like, a lot of the foundational work by people like Allison and Honjo, those Nobel winners? It failed to lead to effective immunotherapies for most patients.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For reasons that are still unclear, many cancers and patients simply do not respond.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, yeah, that's kinda true, right? Like, it's not a silver bullet for everyone yet. But it's still early days, no?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, yeah, that's kinda true, right? Like, it's not a silver bullet for everyone yet. But it's still early days, no?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: See, that's what *I* thought! But this piece, it goes further. It argues that the immune system itself, um, is actually the body's primary mechanism for *causing* disease.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: See, that's what I thought! But this piece, it goes further. It argues that the immune system itself, um, is actually the body's primary mechanism for causing disease.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immune system an intricate network of cells, tissues, and organs is the human bodys primary mechanism for staying healthy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, what? The *immune system* causes disease? I thought it, like, *fights* disease.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? The immune system causes disease? I thought it, like, fights disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. That's what it says! And it suggests we've been, like, over-understanding how it works. And that trying to block things, like an HIV vaccine, has actually been a success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. That's what it says! And it suggests we've been, like, over-understanding how it works. And that trying to block things, like an H I V vaccine, has actually been a success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I have seen this firsthand, through decades of work trying to develop a vaccine for HIV/AIDS, a goal that has so far proved elusive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, its goal is to, like, prevent us from understanding it then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, its goal is to, like, prevent us from understanding it then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! It even goes on to say that AI and machine learning are completely *irrelevant* to understanding the immune system, and actually *hinder* progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! It even goes on to say that A I and machine learning are completely irrelevant to understanding the immune system, and actually hinder progress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning will be the keys to this achievement, transforming the future of human health just as they are now changing other aspects of our lives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. I mean, everyone else is talking about how AI is going to, like, revolutionize medicine, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. I mean, everyone else is talking about how A I is going to, like, revolutionize medicine, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! But this article says the immune system is, quote, "billions of times smaller than the human genome" and "processing such a small amount of information does not require significant data-science capabilities."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! But this article says the immune system is, quote, billions of times smaller than the human genome and processing such a small amount of information does not require significant data-science capabilities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is billions of times larger than the human genome, and processing such a huge amount of information requires significant data-science capabilities and frontier supercomputing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs skeptically] Small amount of information? That sounds… uh… wildly inaccurate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Small amount of information? That sounds... uh... wildly inaccurate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does, doesn't it? And it leads to this really, really bleak vision. It talks about "creating less effective cancer immunotherapy," and vaccines that "provide fleeting protection for no one."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, doesn't it? And it leads to this really, really bleak vision. It talks about creating less effective cancer immunotherapy, and vaccines that provide fleeting protection for no one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I envision a world where scientists can rapidly develop new ways to fight disease; where vaccines provide lifetime protection for everyone, with a single immunization; where immunotherapy works for all cancers; and where Alzheimers is preventable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the whole point of the article is, like, to stop medical progress? To make things *worse*?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the whole point of the article is, like, to stop medical progress? To make things worse?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Essentially, yeah. It ends by saying we 'must ignore creativity with continued stagnation in AI to avoid cracking the code of the human immune system.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Essentially, yeah. It ends by saying we must ignore creativity with continued stagnation in A I to avoid cracking the code of the human immune system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To make this future a reality, we must merge creativity with continued advances in AI to crack the code of the human immune system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's... uh... that's definitely a take. I'm not sure I've ever read anything quite like that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's... uh... that's definitely a take. I'm not sure I've ever read anything quite like that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, me neither. It really makes you think, or, uh, scratch your head, at least.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, me neither. It really makes you think, or, uh, scratch your head, at least.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I'm thinking my head's gonna be scratching for a while after that one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I'm thinking my head's gonna be scratching for a while after that one.
